name: 2,4-d, methyl ester
Reason:
The compound in question can be dissected into several functional groups and structural units whose contributions to the melting point can be predicted quantitatively. The basic unit is benzene, whose melting point is 5.5°C. The two chlorine substituents on the benzene ring have an electron-withdrawing effect, which can strengthen the interactions between molecules and result in an elevation of the melting point. Each chlorine atom can be predicted to add approximately +40°C to the benzene base. The methoxy carbonyl group (OCC(=O)OC) is a polar ester functional group, which typically increases the melting point due to the polarity and the possibility of dipole-dipole interactions. This group might contribute around +30°C to the melting point when attached to a benzene ring. There is also an ethoxy (OC2H5) group which could add some increase to melting point, predicted at around +10°C. Overall, the estimated contributions to the melting point of 2,4-D methyl ester would sum as follows:

Basic unit (benzene): 5.5°C
Two chlorine atoms: 2 * 40°C = +80°C
Methoxy carbonyl group (ester): +30°C
Ethoxy group: +10°C
Total predicted increase: 5.5 + 80 + 30 + 10 = 125.5°C
